Jon Hanna wrote:
>
> Nick Gall wrote:
> > Is the 
> > problem the fact that the PUT request is not providing a
> > representation for the resource (eg an XML document), but is only
> > providing a URL to the representation (via the x-amz-copy-source
> > header)?
> 
> That does make it not do what the spec says PUT does.
> 
> Me, I'd be perfectly happy to see it PUT a resource like <copyFrom 
> xmlns="http://amazon.com/someAmazonDefinedNamespace" 
> href="/sourcebucket/sourceObject" /> and have the server "know" that 
> this represents a resource that would be best represented with a copy
> of the current representation of /sourcebucket/sourceObject and do
> the requested copy.
> 
> Other people will disagree (previous debate on the semantics of PUT
> gets regurgitated here).
> 

Prolly... ;-)  Actually, I don't see why you wouldn't use POST instead
of PUT in your example, and also include the filename of the result in
that XML snippet.  The POST goes to the collection, which creates the
URI requested by the client, then snarfs the original URI, copy made.
Perhaps this goes against the spirit of RFC 2616 (9.5), but it doesn't
go against the spirit of (9.6).

-Eric
